articles.headline: Bannon Is Subpoenaed in Mueller’s Russia Investigation
articles.snippet: The move marks the first time the special counsel is known to have used a grand jury subpoena to seek information from a member of President Trump’s inner circle.
articles.abstract: The move marks the first time the special counsel is known to have used a grand jury subpoena to seek information from a member of President Trump’s inner circle.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Stephen K. Bannon, President Trump’s former chief strategist, was subpoenaed last week by the special counsel, Robert S. Mueller III, to testify before a grand jury as part of the investigation into possible links between Mr. Trump’s associates and Russia, according to a person with direct knowledge of the matter.

articles.headline: Banks Are Big Winners From Tax Cut
articles.snippet: Financial firms are benefiting from the $1.5 trillion tax cut and make up the majority of companies so far handing out raises and bonuses as a result of the law.
articles.abstract: Financial firms are benefiting from the $1.5 trillion tax cut and make up the majority of companies so far handing out raises and bonuses as a result of the law.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The nation’s banks are finding a lot to love about the Trump administration’s tax cuts.

articles.headline: Making Medicaid a Tool for Moral Education May Let Some Die
articles.snippet: There is a precedent for letting states impose work requirements on the poor for medical coverage. It bodes ill for public health.
articles.abstract: There is a precedent for letting states impose work requirements on the poor for medical coverage. It bodes ill for public health.
articles.lead_paragraph: Apparently the plan to Make America Great Again will let some Americans die.

articles.headline: Horror for 13 California Siblings Hidden by Veneer of a Private Home School
articles.snippet: David A. Turpin created the school at his nondescript home southeast of Los Angeles. But what the authorities found inside were his emaciated children chained to furniture.
articles.abstract: David A. Turpin created the school at his nondescript home southeast of Los Angeles. But what the authorities found inside were his emaciated children chained to furniture.
articles.lead_paragraph: PERRIS, Calif. — The private school had a welcoming name. The principal was scientifically minded. But the Sandcastle Day School was a nightmare for the six students enrolled there.
articles.byline: By Louis Keene, Jennifer Medina and Patricia Mazzei

articles.headline: Trump Has Perfect Cognitive Test Score, White House Physician Says
articles.snippet: But President Trump could benefit from more exercise and losing weight, the presidential physician said after Mr. Trump’s annual physical.
articles.abstract: But President Trump could benefit from more exercise and losing weight, the presidential physician said after Mr. Trump’s annual physical.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s White House physician said Tuesday that the president received a perfect score on a cognitive test designed to screen for neurological impairment, which the military doctor said was evidence that Mr. Trump does not suffer from mental issues that prevent him from functioning in office.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Lawrence K. Altman, M.D

articles.headline: Pentagon Suggests Countering Devastating Cyberattacks With Nuclear Arms
articles.snippet: President Trump has not yet approved a draft strategy that would expand “extreme circumstances” for nuclear retaliation to include a crippling cyberattack.
articles.abstract: President Trump has not yet approved a draft strategy that would expand “extreme circumstances” for nuclear retaliation to include a crippling cyberattack.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A newly drafted United States nuclear strategy that has been sent to President Trump for approval would permit the use of nuclear weapons to respond to a wide range of devastating but non-nuclear attacks on American infrastructure, including what current and former government officials described as the most crippling kind of cyberattacks.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and William J. Broad

articles.headline: Ex-C.I.A. Officer Suspected of Compromising Chinese Informants Is Arrested
articles.snippet: The arrest of the former officer, Jerry Chun Shing Lee, 53, capped an intense F.B.I. investigation that began around 2012 after the C.I.A. began losing its agents in China.
articles.abstract: The arrest of the former officer, Jerry Chun Shing Lee, 53, capped an intense F.B.I. investigation that began around 2012 after the C.I.A. began losing its agents in China.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A former C.I.A. officer suspected by investigators of helping China dismantle United States spying operations and identify informants has been arrested, the Justice Department said on Tuesday. The collapse of the spy network was one of the American government’s worst intelligence failures in recent years.

articles.headline: G.O.P. to Use Children’s Health Insurance as Lure for Averting Shutdown
articles.snippet: With no immigration deal in sight, Republicans are eyeing a stopgap bill to keep the government open past Friday, sweetening it with an extension of the child health program.
articles.abstract: With no immigration deal in sight, Republicans are eyeing a stopgap bill to keep the government open past Friday, sweetening it with an extension of the child health program.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With little hope of an immigration agreement this week, Republicans in Congress are looking to head off a government shutdown this weekend by pairing another stopgap spending measure with long-term funding for the popular Children’s Health Insurance Program, daring Democrats to vote no.
articles.byline: By Thomas Kaplan and Robert Pear

articles.headline: It’s Time for Apple to Build a Less Addictive iPhone
articles.snippet: Apple gave us the modern smartphone. Now, it can create a new take on the device by encouraging us to use it more deliberately — and a lot less.
articles.abstract: Apple gave us the modern smartphone. Now, it can create a new take on the device by encouraging us to use it more deliberately — and a lot less.
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s not Apple’s fault that you feel enslaved by your phone. But the company that gave the world the modern smartphone has a perfect opportunity this year to create a brave and groundbreaking new take on that device: a phone that encourages you to use it more thoughtfully, more deliberately — and a lot less.

articles.headline: Google Sells A.I. for Building A.I. (Novices Welcome)
articles.snippet: With a new cloud-computing service, businesses can build their own artificial intelligence algorithms, even if they have little experience with the technology.
articles.abstract: With a new cloud-computing service, businesses can build their own artificial intelligence algorithms, even if they have little experience with the technology.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Google has been using artificial intelligence to build other artificially intelligent systems for the last several months.
